reviewText:
Every time a new Doctor took over the role, some of the Doctor Who fans complained that the new one wasn't a "real Doctor Who".  Generally, they were wrong.  This new one is no exception.

Christopher Eccleston brings considerable talent to the role, and his portrayal is odd and quirky, always a bit distracted, but not exactly like any of the other Doctors, which means that he really has managed to catch the essence of the Doctor.

The Doctor always has at least one companion, generally a pretty female, and this Doctor is no exception.  Billie Piper plays Rose Tyler, who comes off as a bit of an airhead at first, but quickly shows herself to be someone that comes through in a pinch.  Of course, like all of the Doctor's companions, she also shows that she cannot follow simple instructions, but that has been true of every companion since Susan and Barbara.

The sets and costumes are somewhat better, but still a bit cheesy.  Again, like the earlier versions.

In essence, the people making the new series have an obvious respect and love of the earlier series.  No, it isn't exactly like the earlier shows.  If it were just a copy, then it really wouldn't be true to the spirit of the original.

The show is fun to watch.  Once fans of the earlier shows get over the fact that neither Jon Pertwee nor Tom Baker will be back, they'll enjoy this verstion too.

I agree, the new series is a SMASH HIT!  Anyone who gives this 2 stars is just ignorant.  True fans remember the many years that the show was off the air, and are thrilled that it is finally back, especially in the United States. With all the money the BBC put into this series it truly shines with superior visual effects and a phenomenal story line.  Christopher Eccleston is wonderful as the new Doctor, and Ms. Billie Piper is great as his companion Rose.  I love the new interior of the TARDIS, and I am very excited that the show is back after all of this time...  I can't wait to get this on DVD!

Anyone curious for more reviews should check another Amazon listing for this product:

http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00005JO9H

50 reviews averaging 5 stars at last count.  Comments from old and new fans.

I don't know what the other reviewer's problem was but this set is worth it.  I've been a Doctor Who fan most of my life and I found this season to be one of the best.  Christopher Eccleston is a wonderfully gifted actor and gives the role of the Doctor the respect it deserves.  It is an excellent series for old fans, new fans, or anyone interested in science fiction.

I wish I could put neon arrows up pointing to this Amazon listing for everyone who has thought about getting into Doctor Who but doesn't know where to start. Yes, it's an extensive show, and you will become obsessed (if you actually pay attention to it), but it's SOOOOO WROTH IT!
As you may have guessed, I love Doctor Who. It's THE BEST SHOW EVER. If you haven't watched it and you want to get into it, it may be overwhelming to know the show began back in 1963. If you can't watch all of the Classic episodes of Doctor Who, at least start at the beginning of the reboot episodes with this series (season) from 2005. Pay attention to how well the characters are written, and portrayed by the actors, and you'll be able to see past the somewhat cheesy special effects (they were great for the time, and in keeping with the Papier-mch Monsters and rickety sets the classic episodes are so well known for, so give it a chance.).
Chris Eccleston is a wonderful actor and one of my favorite Doctors. As much as I love how the subsequent story lines played out after he left the show, I think the only thing I find disappointing about Doctor Who is the fact that Eccleston only did this one season.

Lots of Cheese ala Star Trek: TNG. Acting is pretty decent. Special effects are all over the place, from the ridiculously low budget sonic screwdriver (a plastic stick with an led light on the end) to very well done solar flare effects torching a room. But the main issue here is that the show revolves entirely around time travel which simply requires a truly massive threshold for suspension of disbelief, unless handled very carefully. Which here it is not. Some people may be able to maintain this level of suspension for long stretches, I simply cannot. Aside from the obvious issues of paradoxes and shifting timelines (which this show does absolutely nothing to address), the even more glaring issue with the plot of this show is that time travel is the ultimate offensive and defensive weapon. (Minor Spoiler) And when they reveal in the second episode that Doctor Who's planet was destroyed and his entire race wiped out in a war, that is the moment when my suspension broke down. With the ability to time travel he could simply go back to any point before then and save his planet in any number of ways (like squashing who ever did it while they were still a single celled organism). And considering his race is called Time Lords, implying they all could travel through time, it is even more inconceivable they could have lost any war ever. And before you might rebut that a benevolent race might elect not to use time travel to harm others or change history, Doctor Who demonstrates time and time again in the show that he has no reservations about killing his enemies or letting them die. And in every episode changing the timeline is exactly what they go around doing. That is why I cannot recommend this show to anyone who has the slightest bit of tendency to judge plots using any logical thought process.
Plays perfect in my US dvd player !

Ordered this as a surprise for my husband's birthday.  He loves Doctor Who and was very excited.

The discs played fine but, upon opening the brand new case, we discovered one of the center binding clips (used to hold the disc display) was broken.  Not only that but the actual seam along the fold of the case itself was 'torn' up to almost the middle of the case.  Not a big deal, I thought.  Sometimes product makes it out that is damaged.  I simply ordered for a replacement item to be delivered.

When this replacement item came, I opened it and again found one of the center binding clips (the opposite side this time) was broken!  I'm frustrated.  We haven't played these discs to see if they have the same issue other buyers have stated.  If so we will be ordering yet another replacement.  If they play fine though, I suppose we will keep this replacement since it isn't as broken as the last.  It is just frustrating to pay for a product and receive it damaged not once, but twice now.

I don't want to risk ordering another replacement because it could be just as damaged as the first item or worse.  Please do a better job monitoring the quality of case production.  Buyers shouldn't have to worry about further damaging a case each time we open it on a brand new product!

I swear, I really tried to like this show.  While I don't chase down sci-fi just for the sake of it, I've enjoyed quite a few movies and TV shows in the genre.  With so many people loving this show, and the fact that it's been on for ten years, I decided to give it a shot.  I fought my way through the first six episodes of season 1 and I just can't take it anymore.  It was like force feeding my kids vegetables with dinner.  In the end they were done, but it was a battle every second.  The cheesiness is at a Sharknado level.  I don't mean the first Sharknado that was so bad it was good.  I mean the ones at the tail end with the robot girl.  Maybe it was fun for a 90 minute movie, but a dozen episodes a year for ten years??  I know some people equate it watching 70's sci-fi today, but it's not even that.  I grew up watching shows like Buck Rodgers and Battlestar Galactic (the original).  I'd rewatch those in a second.  And it's not just the fat ET suits worn by the actors playing aliens.  The plots and the dialogue are also horrible.  I may try jumping ahead a couple seasons to see if it gets any better.  Again, that's only because I really need to know how this show became so popular.

While I liked this new presentation of Doctor Who I felt it came up a bit short. To this day I don't know why Eccleston would not continue for at least another season. The producers really dropped the ball on not requiring at least a second year of him. That being said, it allowed David Tennant (Relative Of Iain Tennant) to step into the role and he is by far my favorite Doctor of The New Revised Series (Tom Baker Is Still My All Time Favorite Doctor). Perhaps it would have been better to have recruited Paul McGann to reprise the role thereby allowing for a better transition since we'd already seen him previously (Well, Most Of Us Had).

Now for the good part. Rose Tyler became perhaps the most dynamic companion ever. She exemplified what men love in women. the girl next door who triumphs over her disadvantages. Meeting The Doctor changes her life and has her fall in love with him (Something That Never Happened In The Previous Incarnation Of The Show). The show had its growing pains but was a worthy successor to its descendent. The new age of the 21st Century is displayed perfectly as we see how England has changed since the late 1980s. More diverse and much more political storylines which suited me just fine. I love how they took the show and slowly and surely brought up new enemies while rehashing some of the older ones quite deftly. I loved how Frazier and Collinson handled this.

The DVD is resplendent with extras and I've already seen it thrice. My first time was in 2007 and the second was in 2012 and the third a month or so ago. I really liked this DVD set. Four Stars. I recommend it highly. I'm the 5419th person to review this great DVD set.

Why doesn't BBC ever reair this season anymore? This was the season that brought back Doctor Who after a decade and I love it! Christopher Eccelston' s 9th Doctor is criminally underappreciated, he brings a sly and witty tone to this time traveling alien and a genuine heart as well, or should I say 2 hearts haha. Season 1also has some pretty great stories as well: Charles Dickens facing alien ghosts, the farting Slitheen, the introduction of Captain Jack Harkness, and of course the return of the Daleks. Season 1 of Doctor Who is defiantly a must- watch for any Whofan, and with Amazon Prime you don't need a TARDIS to watch it again!

I have forced myself to watch around 8 episodes so far.  It has, and is supposed to be - everything that I like most i.e. science fiction, fantasy, futurism, high technology, alien intelligence, etc.
But unfortunately the 3 dollars that was spent on Special Effects for the entire season is an obstacle I am self-admittedly unable to overcome.  I am pretty sure some overhead projector slides from my 4th grade elementary school had more wiz-bang.
Top it off with egregiously bad acting and story arcs likely confiscated from British insane asylums for children, the already weird english screenwriting strips away all hope for the future of humanity.
This is like Hee-Haw cast purposefully recreating a bad 80s SNL skit while using stolen craft projects from a childrens hospital.
I can find no redeemable quality except to allow that if the Brits intended to create a really bad scifi series, they did a great job at it.

This is my absolute favorite season of NuWho. While I may like the following Doctors, and love the preceding Doctors, this season had the right mix of whimsical fantasy-SciFi and serious plot development that made me care and feel for every single character involved, and Christopher Eccleston as the Ninth Doctor captured my heart more than anyone else. Maybe not the best if you don't enjoy the kind of crude humor it serves up (I know, I know... farting aliens who are fat, hardeeharhar), but I feel that it's excellent points far outshine the downsides. British SciFi at its best, if you ask me.

So, my standards for show quality, depth, and effects are based on today's standards.  I have a feeling if I had started watching this show when it first came out, my rating would be higher.  I thought it was okay and, based on all the hype about the show, I'm hopeful that it picks up after the first season.

This was my first real experience watching Doctor Who. Other than aliens and time travel, I wasn't really sure what to expect, especially since there's so much hype surrounding the show. But despite being a bit skeptical, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by this series. It's a bit cheesy and full of loop holes, but the actors do a great job and the characters' interactions are a joy to watch. Also, I know the Ninth Doctor isn't usually people's favorite pick, but I thought Eccleston was truly "fantastic" in the part, and I'm curious to see how the subsequent Doctors measure up to him. That said, the show is not as sophisticated as, say, Star Trek: The Next Generation, but if you're looking for a fun and lighthearted romp through time and space, this fits the bill. As it is, I'm already hooked and am eager to continue watching the rest of the series. Highly recommended.

It is a very enjoyable, unique science-fictional romp.  It is the first season of a cult classic, and does a good job reintroducing the show which started back in 1963 and had ended in the 80's.  In each episode there is an exciting adventure, with many jokes and happy and sad moments.  There is some good acting and some interesting characters.  The science fiction aspect is interesting, enjoyable, but perhaps a tad strange for some people's tastes.  It is not necessarily a perfect reflection of the series entirely as the nature of the show revolves around change.  I'm about hallway through the season and am a big fan of the show, but would say that, so far, it definitely is not my favorite season of Doctor Who, but it is certainly enjoyable and a special show as always.

The new Doctor is amazing, and Rose is the perfect companion.  My daughters and I were instantly hooked and watched all the seasons.  Afterwards I introduced them to some old Doctor Who, and now we're on round 2 of watching all the new ones all over again.  If you like the old Doctor Who, you'll love the new one.

My first experience with Doctor Who was when they ran a marathon on BBC America for the 50th Anniversary.  Nine was my first Doctor and remains my favorite.  He's a very underrated Doctor and even though he only had one season, it was a really good one.  Nine introduced us to the amazing Rose Tyler and the incomparable Captain Jack Harkness.  There were adventures with the Slitheen, living plastic, little boys with gas masks for faces wondering "where's my mummy," and what would a season of Doctor Who be like without the Daleks?! This was a great season and it was the season that reintroduced the series to the world after a long hiatus.

Excellent series. Although he only he only stayed in the role for one season,  Christopher Eccleston's outstanding performance as The Doctor was a hit with fans and helped make the series revival a major success. The first several seasons showrunner Russell T. Davies did an amazing job bringing Doctor Who back as an international success. The next several seasons and specials starring David Tennant  were also outstanding.
After Tennant  and  Davies left the series has dropped a notch or two in overall quality. The present showrunner was a brilliant contributor to the reboot, had written several episodes for the Tennant / Davies years ( Blink, Silence in the Library, & Forest of the Dead ) that are considered classics. However when he took the reins, the shows quality dropped noticeably. Tennant's first successor, Matt Smith played the doctor as a buffoon, basing his interpretation of the role on the 2nd doctor from the 1960's who more or less looked and acted like Moe Howard.
The present doctor is played by a fine actor, Peter Capaldi however the plot lines, stories and budgets are still lacking.
There is a new season of Doctor Who coming in 2017. There is also a new showrunner coming soon after. One thing this series has done since it's inception in 1963 is evolve, sometimes for the better, sometimes not. However the show is always worth a look, even the weakest episodes are generally far superior to most fantasy & science fiction on the tube. In the UK this series is held in high esteem as Star Trek is in the U.S.

A word of advice to Doctor Who newbies: If you try watching season one and find yourself thinking you just wasted an hour of your life, try starting with season two instead. And if Tennant doesn't woo you into Whovianism, skip ahead to Matt Smith in season five. All you need to know are three basic things: 1) The Doctor travels through all of time and space in his ship, which is called the Tardis; 2) his face changes periodically and he's actually really, really old; and 3) if you give it a chance and start in the right place, you'll probably get hooked. Have fun!

Some of these early episodes are a bit clunky. I think the series definitely grew and attained a more consistent level of production values and storytelling. However, Season One builds up to a pretty exciting group of final episodes, especially "The Empty Child" and the arc that follows. Looking back at Eccleston's doctor, I enjoy his rougher edges more now than I did when the show was first on. He provides some genuine explosiveness, and as charming as Tennant and Smith are in later arcs, Eccleston has an authenticity in his character's manic and more grumpy modes.

This, essentially is the beginning of Doctor who in the 21st century. The 13 episodes are elongated to over 5 hours. So, don't forget to see Christopher Eccleston as the Doctor reveal himself more readily with the revamping of the series for the modern  viewing public. Rose is his new companion who takes on a vital role right up to the final episode. The writing for the new series really is energetic with exotic adventures. You must see this series if you want to get the second through the ninth series straightened out. The Doctor and his companions have evolving relationships, much more necessary than the aloof Doctor of the past. Great stuff!

It is a little weird that a very powerful space traveling alien is constantly getting himself into life and death, indeed even apocalyptic scenarios.  You need conflict, otherwise a show is boring, but the conflict in this show is so perpetually cosmic and existential you can't afford to take it seriously- but thats ok!  The show is just a fun.

Really, what can one possibly say about Doctor WHO Season One that has not already been stated at length?  The return of Doctor WHO is one of the pivotal moments in all of television history, and the continuation of a now 53 years-long mythos begins with these episodes starring Christopher Eccleston and Billie Piper, and helmed by Russell T. Davies and Julie Gardner as the creative forces that helped to re-establish the series.  Season One is a lot of fun, and one can see how very quickly, the show finds its footing and sets forth to bring the legend of Doctor WHO back to the forefront of the consciousness of pop culture.

There are many highlights of the first season of "New Who,' including the great Robert Shearman-penned episode, 'Dalek'--the first time the Doctor squares off with his arch-enemies (one Dalek in this case) in any form or fashion since 'Remembrance of the Daleks.  Additionally, the first major contribution made by Steven Moffatt for the revived series is found in this season--'The Empty Child'/'The Doctor Dances'--an awesome two parter that introduces Captain Jack Harkness into Who lore.  'Rose' is an absolutely fantastic episode, while 'Father's Day' at this point seems to be a now-obscure great episode of the series.  The season finale two-parter, 'Bad Wolf'/'The Parting of the Ways,' really shows the gravity and danger of the situations the Doctor courageously faces and will always take on, and the lengths that the renegade Time Lord will go in order to save the lives of the innocent and downtrodden--even if it costs him his life.

At this point, if you are relatively new to the series and have not had a chance to check this season out, you definitely should, for if nothing else, you can really see how the show has grown since its 2005 return, and why, to this day, Eccleston and Piper remain as beloved personalities by Whovians worldwide and across the ages.  Also, since, unless you've bought the discs, Amazon is one of the only ways in which one can view New Who nowadays, it is probably a good idea to subscribe to Amazon Prime to give yourself unfettered access to the show (although frankly, if you take the extra step and buy the blu-rays for all pre-HD episodes of the current series, you will certainly not be disappointed, as clearly, Doctor WHO, in my opinion, is a show that truly shines with crisp, high resolution).

As a lifelong fan of Doctor WHO, I can say without question that Season One is a triumph.  While the first season is not perfect, it nonetheless helps to set the stage for the future of the series and restores to the generations of Who fans around the world, the art form of television, and history in general one of the great treasures of popular culture.  It seems almost surreal that now, so many years removed, the current series is heading into its tenth season stronger than ever.  It all begins (or re-begins, as it were) with these thirteen episodes.

They say you can never forget your first Doctor.  If any of the many actors who have played The Doctor since Dr. Who's premier in 1963 deserves the honour of being your first it is absolutely Christopher Eccleston, a gifted actor whose work you probably know already even if you never connected his name to his diverse roles.

Eccleston only played The Doctor for this single season; he did not renew his contract. But his work here sets the ground work for every Dr. Who episode created since.  Gone is the absent-minded professor type of the first eight Doctors.  Eccleston's Doctor is thoughtful, direct, and action-focused.  This is a Time Lord with a plan who doesn't hesitate to do whatever needs to be done and has both the knowledge and experience to solve problems that would confuse others.

He is also a haunted man, regenerating out of the War Doctor (see "Day of the Doctor" from the 50th anniversary specials), the sole survivor of the Great Time War, his conscience thick with the horrors of that war and his role in it, a conscience that makes him more determined than ever to help others -- starting with Rose Tyler in the first episode, "Rose."

This journey with the Ninth Doctor is far too short, our time with him feeling like the blink of an eye.  But we are better for meeting Christopher Eccleston's Doctor on this journey of discover that will make you laugh, cry, and cheer.

Were it not for Eccleston (Nine) and Piper (Rose) having done such a truly fantastic job this first year, I would not now be so much in love with Twelve.  They admirably met the enormous challenge of getting the new Who off to a solid start as a rollicking good adventure we Whovians are still craving more of even today.  Eccleston's Doctor was perfect: alien enough to intrigue and mystify us, exciting, adventurous, yet approachable enough to make us envy Rose as she gleefully ran to join him in the Tardis, and lovable enough to make us weep as his regeneration into Ten came all too soon.  When I re-watch Who, I always start here--and fall in love with The Doctor all over again every time.

I first heard about Doctor Who from friends and family when the series was rebooted, they kept saying how awesome it was. Every now and then I caught a bit of an episode, but not enough to truly grasp it. About halfway thru the tenth Doctor's first season, I at down and watched a few episodes and got hooked. Now we are re-watching it from the beginning since we finally discovered a place to stream it, thanks to my Amazon prime  membership! I love all the faraway destinations and life lessons it has

It is easy to see how this season of Dr. Who has received so much acclaim.  The episodes offer a veritable feast of imagination and wit, but the zany exuberance often flowers suddenly into moments of the most profound humanity.  For example, the episode about the end of the world is both melancholy and hilariously satirical, while the encounter with Charles Dickens, in spite of the animated corpses, ends in a way which, for me, was quite moving.

This is a really fun show so far---I'm almost completely unfamiliar with Dr Who (outside of having heard of him and the Daleks and knowing what the Tardis is) and it's been very easy to follow.  My 9-year-old has been interested in science fiction lately so we decided to give this show a shot, having heard good things about it.  It's very enjoyable--the episodes so far have been well-written, and have been giving just enough of the show's mythology to keep it interesting without it getting bogged down in exposition.  The effects aren't the best (it's a TV budget from several years ago after all) but they're good enough to further the story in most cases.  It does get a tad silly from time-to-time (the aliens in disguise from one of the early episodes in particular look very goofy) but as a fan of science fiction I think this is going to be a fun show to catch up on.

This was the start of a new generation of Doctor Who. Chris Ecclestien (sp?) tends to get jumped over for the later doctors, but that is a mistake by leaps and bounds. He provides just the right amount of comedy and gravity which made this season a success and provided the step needed to go forward with the series. It is to bad that we only get one season with him, I feel that his role as The Doctor would have only gotten richer over time. Billie Piper is also not to be overlooked as her character keeps The Doctor's feet on the ground. Never skip this season, it may start slow for some, but gets rolling fast soon into the series and before you know it, it is over. One of my top three favorite Doctors!

Just started rewatching the series and as I watched this first season I am charmed all over again.  I'm a New Dr Who fan.  I started watching just a few years ago so I'm not as familiar with the older Drs.  For me it started with 9.  I would love  to watch some of the older episodes one day .  My little girl who is eleven  loves them.  This is a child who considers an 80s movie an " old movie "

But anyway back to this season, it was my first taste of Dr. Who and I fell in love.  Yes I believe the series has gotten better, better stories, better special effects , but these first ones still hold a very special is place in my heart.  It's our first glimpse of Rose.  Our first glimpse of  Captain Jack.  Christopher Ecclestons Doctor is different then the ones that come after him.  He is haunted by the the time war.  He hadn't loved Rose yet.  He is hurting.  As I'm rewatching  this after watching all the other seasons, I appreciate it more and more.

If you are coming here to see what all the hype is about, I wish you well on your journey.  Once you are sucked into the Dr Who universe, it's hard to escape.  A lot of people (I'm told) skip this season. DONT.  It is really worth your time!

Finally! Doctor Who on Blu Ray! I have been waiting for them to release the individual series on Blu Ray ever sincefor the 50th anniversary when they released all of the new Doctor Who series on Blu Ray together. So finally while Doctor Who is in a stint, they've released it and now I can finally add it to my collection. Just be aware that even though these are Blu Ray, they will not be the same quality as Matt Smith or Peter Capaldi era Blu Rays, because of how they were filmed, but there will still be a definite improvement in quality and picture. It comes with a slip cover and has 3 Blu Ray discs that include all the episodes from series 1 (3 Blu Ray discs in total), plus bonus features like Doctor Who Confidential, commentaries, intervies, behind the scenes, and other added features. As far as I can tell, there are no bonus extra features, but they are the same ones from the original DVD release. A must have for Whovians, I am so glad I can finally add this to my collection even though I already own the DVD version for many years (And yes I can never throw that one away even though I now have this one as it is too precious to me!).

If I could only own one series of DVDs, the modern Doctor Who series would be high on my list.  I have literally told people we cannot be friends if they do not watch (and adore) Doctor Who.  We are huge fans!  Whenever someone has come into our circle and is unfamiliar with the Doctor, we always sit him or her down and suck him or her in with The Complete First Series.  Starting when the Doctor introduces himself and tells Rose Tyler to Run! this series will grab the Sci Fi enthusiasts heart!  From silly scenes with a man eating garbage can or a flat human with no understanding of 80s music to tear jerking scenes with characters willing to sacrifice to save others, this series has it all.  And though Christopher Eccleston is not my favorite Doctor, he does an amazing job reintroducing and defining the modern Doctor Who character.

While we own and watch many shows via streaming video, the Doctor Who episodes are shows I don't want to trust to our lousy internet service.  When the internet fails, as it regularly does, I can still watch my beloved Doctor.  Being a huge fan, I also love having access to the behind the scenes bonus material that comes with the DVD set.  Further, with DVDs, we have the option of loaning them out to friends without access to streaming video, since we have undertaken the role of Doctor Who pushers in our circle of influence.

All in all, I am glad I own the Doctor Who DVDs and would highly recommend them!

I stumbled upon the new Doctor Who when David Tennant was The Doctor.  At first I was horrified such a terrible show was on TV, but for some lucky reason kept watching the episode.  As I got into the idea of the show and was willing to suspend belief (a wooden box for a space ship?) David's superb performance drew me in.  I purchased Season One without having watched an episode of Christopher Eccleston's performance.  By then I was hooked and again - willing to suspend belief.  I find the regeneration idea brilliant as is most of the writing.  I am so charmed when a seemingly meaningless detail of a previous episode becomes crucial in a distant one.  I must say I am amazed by the arc of ideas and how cleverly they come together for a brilliant show.  Of course we all have our favorite Doctors, and our favorite companions.  It helps when a favorite leaves that you still have an old stand-by to help you through.  Eccleston is not my favorite Doctor, but he is quite a good actor, and Rose is one of the all time best companions along with the Ponds and River Song and whoever might be just ahead...

This review is specifically for the Blu-Ray released June 21, 2016, beware of reviews that were written before this date, this Blu-Ray was released on June 21, 2016.

The image quality of this Blu-Ray release offers no improved when compared to playing a the DVD on an up-scaling player.  The original footage was not recorded in high-definition, nor was it ecorded on film, so a true HD picture is impossible.

To make matters worse the episodes have been slowed down by 5%, although the pitch of the sound is unaltered the action is 5% slower.  This means each episode is 5% longer, for example the first episode was originally 44.2 minutes now it is 46.4 minuets.  It is doubtful that even the most well-versed Whovian will notice this slight change in tempo, never the less this was not the way the episode was intended ti be viewed.

No improvement of image quality plus slowed down action makes the DVD a better viewing experience than the Blu-Ray.

Wanting to get into Dr. Who? This is the season to watch first.
There was a 15 year hiatus before this season(not including the movie), so they aimed this season at new watchers. It may not be the best season, but it successfully got me hooked(last few episodes starting w/ 9 are when it really gets good, as well as episode 6) and you won't be as confused as if you started w/ a later season.
It's likely to take 3-6 months to watch seasons 1-9 in preparation for season 10 coming up, watching an average of one episode every 1-2 days. If Season 10 is out when you read this, THAT season might be a good place to start if you don't feel like watching 9 seasons first, starting with the Christmas episode at the end of 2016. I have a feeling they'll keep new viewers in mind, with that 1-year hiatus. Also, so many people will be talking about it and you'll really wish the trending topic isn't a spoiler.
As of this writing, I'm almost done with season 2, and I can tell you that it gets even better. Having not watched season 9 yet, my opinion of starting with season 10 might be flawed.

WORD OF WARNING: Do NOT Google ANYTHING for answers. Ask your Whovian friends. Spoilers travel back in time with this show, and all wikis include stuff from later episodes(including things unrelated to your search). I made the mistake of Googling a piece of graffiti that I expected to be a behind-the-scenes reference or a reference to a classic episode. NOPE! Found huge spoilers instead.

TIP: The trivia section of the x-ray view(hit "View All" in upper left corner) is worth reading after each episode. I have found no big spoilers in that section, though sometimes you'll see it point out that something was mentioned, and that phrase or name hasn't been explained yet. It'll be something like "XYZ Reference: A big sign saying XYZ is visible". If you don't even want to know that certain names will be important later, don't view the trivia section.

This is a Classic and Chris Eccelstein was an amazing choice to reintroduce this iconic Show to a new generation. Unfortunately his stint as "The Doctor" was only this inaugural Season but the Whovian Nation was to be introduced to the "Favorite" in David Tennant. As a Man let's be honest the introduction to "Rose Tyler", the Beautiful and Talented Billie Piper, was definitely the bit of Sexy that has since defined an Awesome "Companion" and her Story-Line still remains as some of the Best TV writing of the Series. I know so many Who Fans that are Tennant or Smith "Whovians" but I think it's truly an impossibility to appreciate the entire Plot or understand the whole concept without taking the opportunity to watch Season 1. And how great it is to be an Amazon Prime Member as Doctor Who is only available on Amazon. So take my advice whether you're a Fan wanting to just re-watch some classic episodes or came into the series later and watch and enjoy.

I'm a big scifi buff and very open minded, but this season is just plain bad TV. Why does every episode have to include a cheesy 1950s style alien that is completely implausible...even when you're being generous?

And don't get me started on their gloriously flawed Time Travel theories, which make Back To The Future logic seem almost realistic. Warning, spoiler alert:  First the doc spends several episodes going back in time and changing things around, with no consequence. But when they go back and something gets changed with Rose's dad, all hell breaks lose.

All of a sudden, there is a ripple in time; ridiculously looking 'reaper birds' attack everything there is (aka Stephen King's "The Langoliers" except wayyy cheesier). The doc explains that 'you cannot change the past because it causes huge ripples'....HELLO!!! All he does every episode is change the past (or the future), with absolutely no consequence. Unless, apparently, when it's convenient for the script.

I need to mention that I haven't seen the old shows so I'm only a fan of the "new" Dr. Who, but seeing this in a vacuum was a great experience. The show is fun, cheesy, exciting, and scary all at the same time. It's a bit like The X-Files in that there are one-off episodes and a few meta episodes. I really enjoy thia format because it allows almost each episode to be a concise story that lets you take the show on at your own pace. As for the content of the show, if you are okay with dated CGI and slightly hokey prosthetics, you can enjoy Dr. Who in the fullest due to it's charming characters and wild storylines and locations. The show explores how humans change (and in ways don't) throughout all periods of time and space. We also get to see some truly crazy aliens that also explore human nature and the mystery of the unknown. Overall, I loved this first season and I look forward to watching the other 7 new seasons. I'm not sure what it is about the show, but it is comforting, scary, funny, and tragic all at once. I highly recommend and fan of sci-fi, mystery, and even a bit of action to check it out.

What originally got me into Dr Who was the the actor who played.... well Dr Who or as super fans would correct me and state that it is just the Doctor. Christopher Eccleston was a minor character of the TV series "Heroes" and I thought that he played his role well. Literally that is it... the one in only reason why I watched this show was for the lead actor. Now there are two types of people who have a opinion about Dr Who either they hate it but have never watched it OR the love it and there is nothing wrong with this show and you will love it if you just watch it... Both of these groups are wrong.

Dr Who is a Sci Fi comedy/drama/horror/love story, episodes seem to change the genera from time to time but it is about a dude who is not a dude but an alien that travels through time and space and tends to stop evil aliens doing evil alien... things. Look this is not ground breaking stuff here, its a cheesy Sci Fi show with cheap special effects but its not awful! Well I mean... it is but its not bad, not really good but it is not bad. I got high for a few of the episodes and laughed my ass off, yea there are parts that I cant stand like how ridiculous the Dalek (the Doctors arch enemies) are. Like they are these stupid looking shell robot things with one eye and they just scream exterminate all the time but they are supposed to be the deadliest/ scariest thing in the universe...... Yea no... I don't think so... Look I am getting away from my point which is this; If you never seen this before but want to I suggest just watching it and trying it for yourself don't talk to ANYONE about it though cause either you will get someone who will judge you harshly cause they don't like it even if they have never seen it or you will have someone hype it up so much that you will be disappointed when you do watch it. THEN the guy who hyped it up for you will judge YOU for not liking it... the nerve of them! This it literally one of those things that fans ruin for everyone!! Avoid fans of Dr Who at all cost. How can you tell if someone is fan of Doctor who? Don't worry.... they will tell you!

Over ten years ago, before he was in Thor Dark World and GI Joe: Rise of Cobra, Christopher Eccleston stepped into the role of the UK's favorite alien, the Doctor. With his companion Rose he re-introduced the world to time travel and classic villains like the Daleks. It is a shame his reign lasted only for one season, but he was able to regain the imagination of the world and re-ignite the series. Unlike the old series, these 13 episodes are one hour long each. This is binge watching at it's best as something you miss in one episode could be critical in another!

I remember watching Dr. Who back in the 70s when it was quite advanced effects-wise for TV of the day.  And that sort of production value has a certain amount of nostalgic appeal.  However, as they apparently have done with the updated series, re-visiting those production values for the special effects, isn't nostalgic--it's cheesy, and cheap.  I don't know if the series is on some sort of budget crunch, but it certainly looks like it, even these days when special effects are inexpensive and very convincing. That said, my other issue with this Season is that I keep trying to really like The Doctor, but he gets on my nerves, and there just isn't enough emotional justification for Rose (one-dimensionally played by Billie Piper) to hook up with this guy.  It makes it feel too superficial, and ends up getting boring.  Now, perhaps things heat up a bit, and maybe things get more personal with the characters as the season saunters on.  I've only watched the first 4 episodes.

When you watch, pay close attention to the things around you. With an ending written before the show even started, it gives the ability of foreshadowing the conclusion. That said, this show understands the subtlety of how to foreshadow in a way that you can easily dismiss, but when you get to the end, all of the foreshadowing will add an entirely different meaning to previous episodes.
The characters of The Doctor and Rose are great, and they really do well together. With The Doctor trying to bury the pain of his role in the last great Time War, and Rose broadening her horizons with new and exciting worlds: it all comes together to create an interesting dynamic that is worth the viewers time.
To add one final thing, the humor in this season is great, primarily because it isn't the focus. It's used enough to where if you like it then it flows, but if you don't, then you can ignore it.
All in all, if you want a great season to binge watch, you found it.

The one who started it all...for me...and my minion. My brother was(is) a big fan and kept pushing me to watch it. I thought it would be silly. Finally caved, can only handle so much whining, begging and pleading after all!! It took a while for me to get caught up in the story. My kid loved it immediately. I thought the effects were cheesie, and story silly...but then...
So now my favourite Dr is the tenth one, my fave sidekick is Donna, my kid is an eleventh Dr fan and her life goal is to be the Doctor's sidekick one day. We stare at statues with suspicion and distrust, and decorate for Christmas like the mannequins are coming. When we had the once in a lifetime chance to go to London, we went to as many spots as we could where we knew the Doctor had been. Oh yeah, we just might be fans!!

This series stars Christopher Eccleston as The Doctor and Billie Pieper as Rose.  Of course, the Tardis plays itself in this wonderful series. Campy BBC fun for the whole family. Had a hard time getting into the first few episodes because of the dated special effects, but once I got half way through the first season I was hooked.

Christopher Eccleston does a wonderful job as the Doctor in this revival. His adventures with Rose improve immensely as you progress through the series.  In the early episodes, it is clear that he trying to pull in elements of classic doctors such as John Pertwee or Tom Baker, but these did not seem to translate very well when compared to his demeanor in other parts of other episodes. This leads many to be critical of his portrayal of the Doctor, but he had a huge weight on his shoulders to revive the franchise and the stories he was given were pretty good, but the special effects were clearly not high budget, yet he did a good job with what he was given.  When viewed as part of the whole story since the revival, this series ages well and you can understand the development of the Doctor. I will not be more specific than that. (Spoilers!)

The Blu-rays run 2 minutes longer than the DVDs, the DVDs are compressed.
This isn't true HD-Blu-ray quality, but it is an improvement over the DVDs. Sharper with brighter colors.
This season was NOT shot in HD 1080p, it was shot in British PAL Standard Definition which is 576i.
DVDs have a resolution of 720 x 576 so they are capable of presenting PAL 576i (which has higher resolution than the U.S. 480i NTSC format).
For Blu-ray, the BBC processed the 576i resolution to 1080i, which almost doubles the lines of resolution by imagining (for lack of technical terms) what would have been recorded between the lines.
Your 1080p HD-TV will do this when you plug the DVD player into the RCA "L,R,V" inputs, but the quality varies greatly from TV to TV and is generally not very good.

Upscaling DVD players and Blu-ray Players do a better job than the TVs, but the computer processing used by the BBC is better than some players.

BUT don't expect these to look like the Matt Smith years on Blu-ray.  BBC decided to use an upscale algorithm that introduces many unwanted artifacts.  Stationary shots and closeups look better than the DVD, but on screen motion has aliasing, halos appear on fading gray-scales, or a bad key during effects shots may be more obvious.

AUDIO: The Blu-ray audio on the other hand, is a BIG improvement over the compressed DVD audio.  There is more depth & base.

Christopher Eccleston is simply FANTASTIC as the Doctor. He has saved the series and has forever found a place on my heart as the wounded, emotional destroyed Time Lord from Gallifrey. Without giving you any spoilers, you can not skip this season and call yourself a true fan, as it is Chris' Ninth Doctor, that creates the set up for Tennant's Tenth. It is the love between him and Rose Tyler (yea, Rose fell in love WITH NINE) that gives birth to Ten. The entire series is wonderful and RTD does not disappoint. Plus, the relationship between Nine and Capt. Jack Harkness (the brilliant and loveable John Barrowman) is incredible! Team TARDIS truely shines in this season!

The final scene of the second to last episode which sets up the beginning of the finale WILL GIVE YOU CHILLS! Eccleston shows you the true power of "the Oncoming Storm" in the most chilling speech of the entire series to date!

The finale? Still makes me sob as it is a testimate to how much love the Time Lord's two hearts can truely hold!
Frack yes! Now to get series 2, 3, 4, and have a complete BR who set!
I've been waiting for this to be released on Blu-ray, pretty much forever.  Eccleston is the best Doctor, hands down.

Dr. Who Season One 2004 BBC

Dr. Who must be one of the longest-running TV series in English.  Not that it has run continuously.  It ran for 26 years 1963-1989, then lapsed, then was resurrected again in 2004 and has been running again since then.  There are currently plans to continue it at least into 2017.
This is a sci-fi, family-oriented action/comedy.  The doctor in Dr. Who is a humanoid alien from a race almost vanished, called the time lords.  As might be imagined from this name, he has a nifty sort of space ship that can travel not only in space but time as well.  For reasons not exactly clear, he mostly seems to hang around our planet earth.

I got drawn to look at this after seeing McCoys fine performance as Rhadagast in "The Hobbit" and learning that he had played one of the time lords.  I watched the first season of the resurrected Dr. Who, with Christopher Eccleston as the Doctor and Billie Piper as Rose Tyler, who becomes his human traveling companion.  To illustrate the comedic aspects of this series, the TARDIS space craft is disguised as a blue Police Box [looks like an old style telephone booth] which was extant in London in 1963 when this series began.  Due to a glitch in the chameleon circuitry, it never updates this disguise, even though police boxes have long since vanished from London streets.  But passers by hardly give it a glance.

Billie Piper gives a charming, flirtatious performance as the human sidekick to the good doctor in new Season One.  Eccleston, in a special, says he took on his role as a challenge, because people told him that he couldn't play a comedic-style role and hed never done anything sci-fi [that's what I recollect anyhow].  His smile seems excessive and annoying to me, and I liked his performance better when he looked more serious.  First glimpse at the next doctor already seems more promising overall.

The aliens are as laughable as the spaceship disguise.  One arch-enemy, the Daleks, look like high performance vacuum cleaners with a toilet plunger attachment.  Still the story manages to give a jolt now and then.  It uses the simplest of scare tactics, like having something leap out unexpectedly and with a big noise.  Then you feel ridiculous for having jumped.  The show established several common phrases in England like watching from behind the sofa.  Kids cant help but be fascinated, but don't want to get too scared so theyd watch from behind a sofa ready to pull their head back in when it got scary.  Several generations of Brits and commonwealth members apparently have Dr. Who as a shared experience.  Its easy to see how it developed a cult following.

One of the plot devices allows for the character playing Dr. Who to periodically rotate from one actor to another.  His human companions also rotate periodically allowing the series to go on and on even when one actor gets tired of their role [or the audience gets tired of the actor?].  The downside of course, can be missing a lead actor, when they do leave.

Partway through Season One I thought one season really is enough.  I understand what its about now.  By the end of the season though, I couldn't help myself.  Must see! how Tennant does as the good Doctor!

Having checked out some of the most negative reviews, let me give my take:  Billie Piper looking like she'd rather be anywhere else?  Or her bad acting/bad directing?  I don't know; as an average male [I hope?] I was too busy having fun watching her to think critically about the acting.  I like the casual modern stuff she wears.  They'll clearly date when this was produced.  As for bashing her boyfriend and her mother: let's think about this a minute here.  She's a very average London girl, with a boring job, an irritating and very average mother, a very average boyfriend.  It's pretty easy to see why she might want something way more exciting in her life, even if it is dangerous.  This is the sci-fi version of "join the army see the world be the best you can be" I suppose.  The bigger question would be: what does Dr. Who see in HER?  Yes I'm sure it gets pretty lonely being the last one of your own race and living 900 years as a single guy.  In that case, and since brains don't seem to be her strong suit either, why doesn't he put more obvious moves on her?  [yes, it might make the plot too serious, and might make it harder to sell as family-fare maybe].  Whatever the reason, her character is basically someone to talk to for The Doctor, and they keep a steady, low boil of sexual tension between them, throughout the season.  Just sayin.

As for her boyfriend: does ONE GUY damn the entire darker-colored portion of our species as being "cowardly"?  That itself seems like a racist notion to me.  Anyhow his character is probably no more cowardly than most people would be if invited to fly off in a space-time ship with an alien.  Aren't young people warned about taking a ride in a car with a stranger?  What of a ride in a space-time ship with an alien whose intentions you really don't know?  The screwball in this relationship, if there is one, is Rose.  What else?  He's crazy about her.  They seem equally matched intellectually.  He's NORMAL.  Neither of them make a deal about their mixed ethnicity.  Neither does her mom.  And toward the end of season one, the boyfriend finds his testosterone too.

"Rubber racism": the complaint that the aliens in rubber suits, the Daleks, all of the special effects being cheesy: D'oh!  YEAH!  This is what makes the series a COMEDY.  This isn't "Alien", m'kay?  Actually, I got fascinated watching the eye movements of the Slitheen.  Cheesy as the rubber suits may have been, they were interesting too.  The opening sequence for each episode, with the low-budget sci-fi soundtrack, the swirling red sort of tunnel and the ridiculous blue phone box spinning through it: laughable as this looks, I actually started looking forward to it.  Oh boy-- time for some FUN!

I think [without looking up a technical definition] this qualifies as high camp.  A series with sci-fi, horror, drama, all this and LESS!  It doesn't take itself too seriously, so you know you needn't, either.  Somewhat like a TV version of old fashioned comic books.  Finally, the price for the box set is now a lot lower than it started out [still might seem pricey to some] and it does have sub-titling now.  Yes I guess it would have been nice to include the entirety of the bonus features, especially at this price point.  But soon I'll be viewing time lord #10.  If you don't hear from me again, maybe I got stuck at 1,000,000 A.D. in earth's future.
Hours of pleasure from this classic show, pleased with delivery and product.

I got hooked the first time I saw Doctor Who on TV.  So much so, that I have bought almost every single Doctor Who seasons/series on dvd (i.e. the ones where Christopher Eccleston, David Tennant and Matt Smith play as The Doctor).  I still cannot accept or watch Peter Capaldi as The Doctor, because (1) his heavy Scottish accent is hard to understand, and (2) he played Caecilius in the "Fires of Pompeii" episode of Doctor Who (I just keep seeing Caecilius whenever I see Capaldi play as The Doctor).

In this series Christopher Eccleston plays as the Doctor, and Billie Piper plays as Rose Tyler.  Both actors were "fantastic" (as Eccleston's Doctor says at the end of this series).

The writing/scripts are excellent.  Everything starts with the writing/story, then everything else builds from there.  The acting is great, the music is great, the visual effects are great, etc.

I have watched the Christopher Eccleston, David Tennant and Matt Smith Doctor Who series FIVE times, and will probably rewatch them again!  That is how good everything is in these series.

Funny thing is, after watching them five times, I am finally seeing scientific improbabilities/mistakes and some plot holes. This series must be great, since I did not notice these mistakes during my first three viewings.

"The Long Game" episode in this series is very very metaphoric of today's world (i.e. an allegory to our world today).  So much so, I cannot believe the BBC allowed this episode to air.

I really loved Christopher Eccleston as The Doctor.  I wish he would have done more than just one season/series.
I also loved Billie Piper as Rose.  I wish she would have done more than just two seasons/series.  However, she does appear as a guest star a number of times in future series.

It's a shame Chris Eccleston only last one season as the Doctor.  I thought his interpretation of the role was truly brilliant, not seen before or since. I never watched the Doctor Who episodes from the 60s, 70s, or 80s.  This was my introduction.  Eccleston does a great job as the eccentric Time Lord who craves adventure, gets to ultimate danger, scares the heck out of people and shrugs it off with a "faux smile".  I watched the first episode, Autons, and was hooked.

So many other reviews have focused on the episodes themselves - or comparing to the original series.  I'll avoid that.  I'll say that if you start here - you'll get a real sense for whether you want to proceed to future seasons.  The episodes are quite varied from back in time, to in the future, to single episodes, to multi-part.  Eccleston played it marvelously as an eccentric doctor who wants to do the right thing and have a lot of fun in the process.  I tended to be a little more sceptical of the fanaticism of Doctor Who - yet I quickly watched every episode - and 2 weeks later was disappointed that Eccleston moved on.  But the story line continued; the other characters stayed on; the Doctor regenerated into the great David Tennant, and the entertainment continued.

Unlike some TV programs; or even other Doctor Who seasons, I could watch this one repeatedly.

People have been after me since I was 14 to watch Doctor Who.  Every guy I dated in high school or college was a fan.  But I never watched it.  That was back when it was classic Doctor Who, way back in the olden days.  Then my adult daughter wanted me to watch so finally I tried it, watched two episodes of this with her.  I was mildly intrigued, but was busy going through all the Star Treks for the first time.  Once I finished those, I sighed and said, "Well, okay, let's get Doctor Who over with."  Unsure where to start, because I thought every new incarnation of the Doctor meant a new set of seasons, I just started with the first one I found a season one of, which turned out to be this one.  I watched those same two episodes that my daughter had showed me, plus all the rest.  Now I'm hooked.  Don't know if I will like it as much next season without Eccleston, but other fans say that I'll love Tennant as well or even more.  We shall see.  But the main reasons I watch the show are for the relationships and for the sass!  If the sass isn't as good next season,  I just don't know.  But I just loved Eccleston.  I recommend binge watching it though, if you've never seen it, because it gives you a better flow for what's going on, and kind of, for who the Doctor is.  And you can only tell if you'll like it by giving it a chance.  So if you haven't seen it, give it a chance!

In 2014, I made a goal for myself...to watch all 50 years of Doctor Who; every available serial, episode, movie, and special...and I gave myself one year to do it. It took eight months, but I eventually achieved my goal, and just in time for the 50th anniversary special. I then decided to buy/own my absolute favorite serials/episodes from each Doctor, and these were some of them.

I truly believe Doctor Who wouldn't have become the global phenomenon it is today without the 2005 relaunch of the series. Christopher Eccleston's Ninth Doctor is wise and funny, cheeky and brave. And his companion, Rose, was the down to Earth, average teenager the whole audience could relate to. As they travel together through time, encountering new adversaries, the Doctor shows her things beyond imagination. Some of my favorite stories from this season included "The End of the World" (where the Doctor shows Rose the eventual fate of the planet Earth); "Dalek" (the bitter sweet, but still chilling return of the most famous enemies of the show); and "The Empty Child/The Doctor Dances" (a gripping and scary two parter set in WWII, featuring zombie kids in gas masks, and the first apperance of heroic heart throb, Captain Jack Harkness).  And it all leads up to an exciting two part season finale with a showdown with the Daleks, and a tearful changing of the guard, in which the Doctor regenerates into his Tenth form.

It's a shame the Ninth Doctor only lasted a season, because he was pretty good, and this series was pivital in not only reintroducing the classic series to the modern era, but also laying the ground work for all the important elements that would make the modern era of Who the success that it is today.  And the discs are all jam packed with interesting special features, including behind the scenes info about the making of the show, and interviews with the cast members.

Thanks to this important first season, the Doctor is in again, and Tardis is here to stay.

I remember Doctor Who from the old, old series with the amateurish special effects and such.  This series has much better special effects and production quality.

Davies takes a dawdling 20th century Sci-Fi series and turns it into a gripping and thought-provoking show.  Eccleston's Doctor and his sidekick, Rose, are both fans of adventure, especially with a chance of danger.  Spoiler alert: they find plenty of both, with polished supporting actors throughout. If you are here, you love Doctor Who so I won't be reviewing the stories. What I will do is list all of the episodes in this set because when I was looking to purchase ALL of the episodes including the specials, I had trouble finding out exactly what was in each set. Not knowing that, I had to order them and compare the episodes against the actual master list from the BBC. Season one is complete with no missing specials. The following are included in "The Complete First Series".

1 "Rose"
2 "The End of the World"
3 "The Unquiet Dead"
4 "Aliens of London"
5 "World War Three"
6 "Dalek"
7 "The Long Game"
8 "Father's Day"
9 "The Empty Child"
10 "The Doctor Dances"
11 "Boom Town"
12 "Bad Wolf"
13 "The Parting of the Ways"

After Season 4, the BBC aired 4 special episodes and are available on DVD and Blu-Ray as "Doctor Who - The Complete Specials". This is a 5 disc set with David Tennant (the 10th Doctor on the cover). They aired before Season 5. The Complete Seventh Series did not include "Doctor Who - The day of the Doctor (50th Anniversary Special)" or "Doctor Who - The Time of the Doctor" and must be purchased separately.

This is the first season of the cult television series Doctor Who, after a long break. And I think that the first season was very interesting, full of humor and at the same time dramatic. Christopher Eccleston is perfectly embodied in the Ninth Doctor. His cynicism is merely a mask because he is with all my heart worries about the fate of humanity. He again spoiling for a fight and not going to give up in the face of difficulties. His new companion, whom he had successfully played Billie Piper, fully shared his interests and is not afraid to take on any adventure full of dangers. Each episode is interesting and unusual, some scenes really forced to worry about the fate of the characters. I really liked 1 season and I still revising. Thank you to all the creators of the series!

i'm a long time fan of classic Doctor Who. When this series came out in 2005, i was... anxious as to what it might be like. Now, after 7 series of new Doctor Who, i am sure that this is indeed my Doctor Who. It's bigger, more emotionally involving, and way higher budget, but it really is Doctor Who. It's Doctor Who for the current era.

Out of the current new series, series one, with Christopher Eccleston, is my favorite. It's the least goofy. i can deal with some charming silliness and humor is definitely a must, but series one has much less eye-rolling goofiness than the following series (and series seven had some embarrassingly bad moments, i should add).

If you're a classic Who fan, you probably already own this. If not, give it a try on Netflix first. The BBC did us right. This really is new Doctor Who.

After watching all of the Torchwood series, I decided it was time to watch "the original," so to speak. "The Doctor" is mentioned often in Torchwood.

Interesting tidbits: Eve Myles who plays Gwen Cooper, one of the main characters in Torchwood, appears in Episode 3 of Doctor Who. Her character lives in Cardiff, just as Gwen Cooper did in Torchwood, and just as in Torchwood, she saves the world, although she dies in Doctor Who. Naoki Mori who plays Toshiko Sato, another of the main characters in Torchwood, appears in Episode 4 of Doctor Who. It's just a small part, but there she is! (I haven't seen all of Season 1 yet, so there may be other appearances by other Torchwood actors. I've heard that Captain Jack of Torchwood has a "thing" for the Doctor, so I wouldn't be surprised to see an episode featuring him.)

Christopher Eccleston, The Doctor, has a comical grin he flashes a lot. To me, it's just plain weird and unsettling. Billie Piper, Rose Tyler, has her moments, but didn't seem to be a good actress in the first few episodes. She's getting better -- maybe her character is written to be "slow." I don't know.

The actual plots are fairly compelling. Some of the effects are quite special, but seeing a Time Lord from way in the future fix some high tech equipment by hitting it with a hammer just seems stupid. I know I wouldn't whack my computer to make it work better. I also found it odd that the actual meaning of TARDIS is given once in the first episode and then never again, even when a new character is invited inside. (Pay attention or be prepared to look it up online.)

I keep watching, hoping it will live up to its reputation.

It's such a shame Christopher Eccleston was just the Doctor for one series. This set is a great way though to get introduced (or even re-introduced) to everyone's favorite Time Lord. This series features the 9th Doctor with one of his most memorable companions, Rose Tyler. This series is a great way to get to know fan favorites like the Daleks and Cybermen. Keep an eye out for references to Bad Wolf as you watch this series. (You can also get this set on Blu-ray, but it's just upscaled from the SD version.)

Episodes in this set include:
1. Rose
2. The End of the World
3. The Unquiet Dead
4. Aliens of London
5. World War Three
6. Dalek
7. The Long Game
8. Father's Day
9. The Empty Child
10. The Doctor Dances
11. Boom Town
12. Bad Wolf
13. The Parting of the Ways

I'm so glad I got drawn into watching the series before reading any reviews here.  I might have been misled.

Yes, the show is campy.  Yes, the production values would make Spielberg weep.  Yes, absolutely; the Daleks and pretty much every other menace in this first season are painfully lacking in menace.  Yep, that's an egg-beater that Dalek is pointing at the human race.  The action is indeed sort of silly if you give yourself time to analyze it.  Many of the plot twists drop the story right off the expressway into the ditch and the whole contraption crumbles under the least pressure from logic.

Who cares??!

It doesn't matter.  The reason it doesn't matter is in the show's name.  Either you love him and his friends and will follow their adventures to whatever outrageous corner of the universe, or you don't.  It's not for everyone.

However, if you're considering giving Dr Who a go, don't be put off by all the reviewers here who take the show to task for being "dumb" and so forth. This show is pure fun, like a brilliant carnival ride; with its noisy generator, greasy nuts and bolts in plain view, and the slightly creepy carney guy who buckles you in. It's perfectly clear right from the beginning of episode 1 when the first mannequins come to life, that the greasy nuts and bolts are gleefully, deliberately, on display.  Just buckle in and keep your eyes on the Dr.

We have more than enough movies whose slick appearances are their biggest raison d'etre.  Yech.  I just hope Hollywood never cottons-on and tries to get into this franchise.

I am one of the stodgiest (in the nicest way, of course) people you could meet, but the new 21st century regeneration of Dr. Who in every instance has me captivated.  I have watched every episode of every season (1-7) multiple times and still catch such clever (and so often hilarious) moments in the Dr.'s lines.  I have loved every regeneration of the Dr. and got teary eyed when each one was replaced.  I just have to say, what an amazing vehicle for unlimited fantasy the Dr. Who idea is!  I also deeply appreciate that we aren't jerked out of the fun and fantasy by explicit sexual material.  I think that is what makes Dr. Who (at least so far and I hope it continues) a program that leaves us all (from child to adult) with so much to be intrigued by and left to imagine.

You have to have a bit of tolerance, or even preference for the goofy to really get into Dr. Who. It's really hard at times to take it seriously, particularly where the special effects are concerned. However, it can be completely endearing once you get into it.

The thing I like the most about Dr. Who is that it is sci-fi, it is action-adventure, but what it isn't is dark and moody like a lot of other pieces of its genre. It's a light-hearted fix of an action show. But then, not always; it does have just enough of seriousness spread out across the season to keep you engaged and anticipating outcomes and the story of the main characters.

I've only seen two doctors (Eccleston and Tennant), but I want to take a moment to comment on Eccleston's Doctor. When I first started watching, I thought his portrayal was strange and even a bit detached. As the series went on, however, I realized that his performance is anything but detached, and he actually did a really good job bringing to life a character who is extraordinarily complex. He is often warm and wise, but he fluidly switches to a cold and lethal persona. All in all, his performance really made the Doctor into someone to be fond of and have great respect for. I'll really miss his portrayal after watching this season.

All in all though, if you like sci-fi and don't want to feel depressed after watching each episode, definitely give this one a try :)

Many years ago, I watched Doctor Who on PBS when I could, but I lost track of The Doctor when I moved to Arkansas in 1992.

Now that I've got Amazon Prime, I'm delighted to see that they have many seasons of Doctor Who, both original and rebooted series.

I decided to watch the reboots first, and I'm enjoying them as much as I remember enjoying the older doctors.

Though the doctors change, and the companions change, I like the way that it happens logically. I better understand how and why The Doctor regenerates, and I even understand how each of the Time Lords (back where there were more than one) chose their names, as our multiply-lived "The Doctor" chose his.

I like the way that the producers and writers found creative ways to keep bringing back the various bad guys, and I like the way that some of the so-called villains are not always villainous, but merely seeing life from a different perspective.

Don't forget to watch the specials. They are longer so usually have extra time to spend on a particularly special story. Some of them include "Making Of" episodes that show how much of the filming happened, and other trivia.

While it isn't necessary to watch the seasons and specials in any particular order, you can find complete listings of the episodes online.

The copy I found shows this order for the reboot:

Reboot Season One: 9th doctor
Reboot Season 2-3-4: 10th doctor
David Tennant Specials: 10th doctor
Reboot Season 5: 11th doctor
Special: A Christmas Carol
Reboot Season 6: 11th doctor
Special: The Doctor, the Widow and the Wardrobe
Reboot Season 7: part one (5 episodes)
Special: The Snowmen
Reboot Season 7: part two (8 episodes)

and of course, there are also Special Specials that do not fit anywhere in the timeline above

DW: Best of the Doctors
DW: Best of the Monsters
DW: Best of the Companions
DW: Best of the Christmas Specials
DW: The Companions

If you enjoy time travel, sci fi, fantasy, or just plain fun, try Doctor Who?

John

For those who long for The Good Old Days of Doctor Who, this isn't it. The 21st century Doctor is more fast-paced than incarnations of old. We focus more on the companions and their lives. They no longer exist just to say, "What is it, Doctor?" My favorite actor will always be Tom Baker because he was my first Doctor. First-time viewers will suffer the same nostalgia decades from now.

It might be helpful to go back and view old episodes just to get a running start. Maybe even just the special shows The Three Doctors, The Five Doctors, and The Two Doctors will be enough to give historical flavor, even though these will not have Tom Baker. Okay, add The Keys To Time set of six. Maybe Baker's first episode Robot just so you can see Sarah Jane Smith. And some of Pertwee while banished to Earth so you can experience UNIT, and the lovely Jo Grant at his side. And any episodes with Daleks. And Cybermen. And the Master. And....?
It's Doctor Who. Need I say more? Watching this series is the best television decision you'll ever make. Do it!

I had always avoided the old Doctor Who shows because I thought they were just a little too cheesy. After a bit of convincing, a coworker finally got me to try Episode 1 of the reboot of the show. The adventure, emotion, humor, and sometimes creepiness of the show keep me coming back again and again.

Since Eccleston was my introduction to The Doctor, I have always compared the others to him and found them to be good, but missing the unhinged, humorous, manic energy of season 1. The only drawback is that Mickey is such a whiner. I get it that it is his place in the story, but seriously, he needs to grow a spine or find a six-pack of self esteem.

If you are even a slight fan of Science Fiction, WATCH THIS SHOW FROM THE BEGINNING. You will thank me later.

I started off my experience with Doctor Who by watching the fifth season (or series, as the Brits call it), featuring my personal favorite Doctor, Matt Smith.  I then went on to finish the last few seasons of the series, and yet I wanted more.  I decided to go back to the first season, and while I wouldn't recommend watching the show in that order, it was still incredibly satisfying, and filled in a few gaps of the Doctor Who universe that I hadn't yet learned about (i.e. Bad Wolf, Captain Jack, etc.).  At first, I found some of the effects used in the show to be somewhat amusing, since I suppose the BBC didn't have as large of a special effects budget back then.  However, you get used to it pretty quickly, and besides, that's not where the beauty of Doctor Who lies.  If you're interested in space,  time travel, the English accent, or all of the above, you're guaranteed to have a blast watching this show.  I just wish that I had found out about it earlier than I did, but, as they say, better late than never!
Just awesome television.  Shame American television isn't as good. Let's your mind wander free. Doesn't get any better than this!

Doctor Who needs little introduction - a TV sci-fi series that started way back in the 1960's that ran more or less continuously until the late 1980's and was required Saturday night viewing for generations of British kids. It was notable for it's scary monster of the week theme, the changing title role, the Doctor's slightly ramshackle mode of conveyance and the variety of "Doctor's Companions". Sadly, it was also notable for it's limited budget, wobbly sets and man-in-a-rubber-suit aliens. However, despite its failings, it gained a special place in the nation's conciousness and is looked back on with fondness by many.

After a seventeen year break, the series restarted in 2005 with Christopher Ecclestone as the tenth Doctor, Billie Piper as his travelling companion Rose and Russell T Davies behind the typewriter to carry the Series through 13 episodes, to wit:
- "Rose"
- "The End of the World"
- "The Unquiet Dead"
- "Aliens of London"
- "World War Three"
- "Dalek"
- "The Long Game"
- "Father's Day"
- "The Empty Child"
- "The Doctor Dances"
- "Boom Town"
- "Bad Wolf"
- "The Parting of the Ways"

This first of the "reimagined" series has some strong themes, largely based around the Doctor's somewhat patronising admiration for the terribly backward, parochial yet still wonderful people of Earth and his developing (but of course, chaste) relationship with Rose Tyler. It does struggle however, oh yes. The monsters are still mostly rubber suits (human-inhabited or not), most of the scrapes are solved (or at least mitigated) by means of the ubiquitous sonic screwdriver, and the elephant in the room is that all of those scrapes /could/ simply be sorted by the Doctor popping forward (or backward) in time a few more years. Also, while Ecclestone clearly wanted to develop an unique persona - slightly unhinged but terminally optimistic - his mad, bouncy grin simply annoys.

I suppose one can forgive, however. After nearly two decades away, some time would be needed to bed in and find feet. And there ARE some outstanding episodes, in particular "Dalek" and "The Empty Child"/"Doctor Dances". Also, several new and subsequently recurring characters make their entrances; Harriet Jones and Jack Harkness, to name but two, and there are some sweet cameos to spot as well. Interestingly, there is also the genesis of several recurring references and story arcs that make themselves felt in subsequent series, such as "Bad Wolf" and The Time War. Finally, we are also introduced to Mark Gatiss who is a huge asset to the franchise in his recurring and intermittent role as screenwriter ("The Unquiet Dead").

In the end, however, I felt that the series was a bit of a letdown - not half as good as I remembered it to have been when I watched it with my (then) pre-teen daughter. It is nevertheless good entertainment and essential viewing if for no other reason (and it's NOT the only reason) than to provide continuity into the next series.

The five discs come with a short "making of" documentary for each episode, plus various trailers commentaries and video diaries.
